if you were ever on a 2 week schedule you could release a 15 song album with music videos in 7 months, what makes an album seem unappealing?

@X

12.6.19  10:45 pm   11.28.18 10:32 am bill it's me, again the guy from one year ago who talked about the question from a year prior. In 2019 i vaguely applied your advice, I wanted to follow in your footsteps of self-documentation and I kept a journal nearly every single day so now I have all the days listed in front of me and all my thoughts and feelings for each day etc. I have come again to seek more advice for the upcoming year and new decade. I guess my question is how do I make the most of the new decade?

     the only advice i have that is to get a good look at the way the date looks on january first. looks ridiculous, i always enjoy that. if you are looking to shape and plan your future, please i am begging you don't do it on january first, unless you want the whole thing to be fake. january first resolutions are so famous for failure, i just wouldn't even go there. pick a time table that is so uniquely your own that it will be destined to succeed just on the power of its pure uniqueness

12.6.19  10:02 pm   Would you like to be on my Podcast?

     yes

12.6.19  9:48 pm   hey, just curious if you remember what it was like transitioning into writing the roadmap for songs before you record them, assuming you did it a different way before. like how did you learn?

     not really a transition.... i've tried both, and when i don't write it first, it just doesn't have the freedom to go where it wants to go. As i'm saying this now, i can see that it appears backwards, but the reason is because when you're recording a song there are lot of instruments and parts to deal with, so you can't very easily change the way the song goes, on a whim. I've found that it's a much greater advantage when you write the song before anything is recorded, because you can make the song go anywhere, on a whim. you just write it there and it goes there. in other words, writing is not like writing multiple instruments. i don't write the instruments, i write the *song*. which consists of melody+lyric+chords, all the way through, and knowing the exact tempo. The process of translating that into instruments only happens once the song is written. it's probably a lot like animating a cartoon. it's pretty hard to improvise a cartoon. you kind of have to know how it goes before you do it. you CAN however, improvise a cartoon by acting it out, improvised. then based on the recorded improv, make the cartoon. similarly, a song could be made by improvising it using 1 instrument and voice, and then constructing the arrangement based on that recording. i forgot the question

12.6.19  9:42 pm   if you had to permanently dye your hair some unnatural color, what would it be

     dark purple

12.6.19  8:45 pm   what if you were stuck in a hallmark christmas movie 

     no one is stuck in a hallmark christmas movie, those things are filmed extremely quickly
